claim.hypotheses_location: Introduction / theoretical framework (paper discusses hypothesis that political polarization reduces government size and that this effect is stronger in well-developed democracies)
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Introduction (paper states the main finding that political polarization correlates with smaller government size in democratic countries but not in undemocratic ones)

data.source: World Values Survey (WVS) individual responses for political preference questions; government consumption and transfers data from Gwartney and Lawson (2008) using World Bank and IMF sources
data.wave_or_subset: Primarily WVS 2000 wave, with some use of 1995 wave to increase sample size
data.sample_size: Primary analyses cover ~83 countries (some specifications report 74 countries; various subsamples for strong vs. weak democracies)
data.unit_of_analysis: Country-level aggregates (polarization measures aggregated from individual WVS responses); some measures computed separately for government vs. opposition supporters
data.access_details: Data sources referenced as WVS and Gwartney & Lawson (2008); supplementary appendix available online (no direct download/link provided in the paper summary)
data.notes: Polarization measured as dispersion of individual responses (standard deviation, Esteban-Ray, bipolarization). Potential measurement issues noted: responses may be relative to current size of government, high correlation among polarization measures, possible measurement error in weak democracies; some analyses instrument polarization using previous survey waves. Multiple country-sample counts reported across specifications.

method.description: The study constructs country-level measures of political polarization from individual World Values Survey responses to economic policy questions (EQUALITY, PRIVATE, GOV, COMP), primarily using the standard deviation as the main polarization metric (alongside Esteban-Ray and bipolarization measures). These polarization measures are merged with country-level fiscal outcomes (government consumption as fraction of total consumption; transfers/subsidies as fraction of GDP) and other control variables. The paper estimates OLS regressions of government size on polarization under three specifications (basic, short, long) and splits the sample by level of democratic development (Polity IV index into strong vs. weak democracies). Robustness checks include alternative polarization measures, additional controls, interaction terms with legislative fragmentation and government seat shares, and instrumental variables using previous survey waves.
steps: Compute polarization measures from WVS responses to four economic policy questions (std. deviation, Esteban-Ray, bipolarization) at the country level.
Aggregate polarization measures overall and separately for government supporters and opposition supporters; compute ideological coherence and other derived indices.

Merge polarization measures with country-level fiscal outcomes (GOVCONS: government consumption as fraction of total consumption; GOVTRANSSUB: transfers/subsidies as fraction of GDP) and control variables (geographic dummies, colonial origin, GDP per capita, Gini, trade openness, demographic variables, federal structure, OECD membership, Polity IV democracy score, etc.).
Classify countries into strong vs. weak democracies using Polity IV and run separate regressions for these subsamples.

Estimate OLS regressions under three specifications (basic, short with geographic/colonial controls, and long with additional potentially endogenous controls) with heteroscedasticity-robust standard errors.
Include interaction terms to test mechanisms (e.g., polarization × HERFGOV, polarization × GOVSEATS) and test effects of polarization among government supporters vs. opposition supporters.
Run robustness checks (alternative polarization metrics, different samples, additional controls) and attempt IV estimation by instrumenting polarization with previous WVS waves where possible.
method.models: Ordinary least squares (OLS) regressions with heteroscedasticity-robust standard errors; specifications include basic/short/long sets of controls. Interaction models (e.g., polarization × measures of government fragmentation). Instrumental variable (IV) specifications using previous survey waves for polarization in some robustness checks.
method.outcome_variable: Primary: GOVCONS (government consumption as a fraction of total consumption). Secondary: GOVTRANSSUB (transfers and subsidies as fraction of GDP) and other measures of redistribution.
method.independent_variables: Primary: country-level political polarization (standard deviation of WVS responses on economic policy questions: EQUALITY, PRIVATE, GOV, COMP); alternative polarization measures (Esteban-Ray index, bipolarization); polarization among government supporters and opposition supporters; ideological coherence measures.
method.control_variables: Geographic dummy variables, colonial origins, GDP per capita, Gini income inequality, trade openness, demographic factors (population density, age structure), federal structure, OECD membership, Polity IV democracy index, measures of press freedom (PFREEDOM), confidence in parliament (CONFIDENCE), corruption index (CORRUPTION), turnout, legislative fragmentation measures (HERFGOV, HERFLEG), government seat shares (GOVSEATS), property rights (PRIGHTS), and other political/institutional indicators depending on specification.

results.summary: The study finds a robust negative correlation between political polarization and government size, particularly in well-developed (strong) democracies. In strong democracies, higher voter polarization is associated with lower government consumption; this relationship is robust across many specifications and polarization metrics. No consistent negative relationship is found in weak democracies. Results are robust to several control sets and alternative measures, though IV estimates are imprecise in some cases. Interaction tests suggest stronger relationships when governments are more fragmented, consistent with veto-player logic, but interaction coefficients are not uniformly significant. The paper does not definitively establish causal mechanisms.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Change in GOVCONS per 1 SD increase in polarization (strong democracies)
Coefficient on polarization (GOV measure) in strong democracies (selected specification)
numerical_results.unit: units of the dependent variable as reported in paper (scale unspecified in summary)
